captions.text: What is this?
This Is Cat Mojo 101.

The ultimate, the archetypal,
the omniscient and omnipotent,

the all consuming, all
knowing, Cat Mojo 101,

let's get prehistorically
moj-ified, cat-ified, let's
go-ify right now.
Unh!

So a funny thing
happened to me on the way
to making this here video.

The thing is, I thought
I made this here video.

I thought I made this
here video 1,000 times

over in my head,
which was the problem.

Because I made this video 1,000
times over my head, and never
actually made it to this.
What is Cat Mojo?

It Is what propels a cat
forward through this lifetime

with confidence, with
security, with the knowledge

that I am doing what I was
put on this planet to do.

Now fortunately, cats got
it made a lot better than we

do, because we spend our
entire lives, you know,

going to like Liberal Arts
college, trying to figure out,

like what is it I'm
on this planet to do?

Cats know from the
moment they're born.

So the way we're
going to break it down

is, this here fork that
I'm holding in my hand.

The first prong of the
Fork of Mojo is what?
The Confident Who.

The second prong of the
Fork of Mojo-- bing,

that would be the
Confident What.

And finally, the
Confident Where.
Who is the Confident Who?
Confident Who is the Raw Cat.

The Raw Cat is that cat way in
the back of your cat's head,

thousands and thousands
and thousands of years ago.

That African desert cat that
is the hunter, the catcher,

the killer, the eater,
the groomer, the sleeper.
Bang!
That is the Raw Cat.

The process of quote,
"domesticating" cats

has been nothing like
domesticating dogs.

Dogs, we basically take
them out of the wild.

We say you know
what, I like you.

I like what you do, I want
you to do a job for me,
act like this.

And when we started
storing grains and whatnot,

we said wait a minute, the
cat's killing the mice,

and the things that
are ruining our food.
Let's keep them around.

So we didn't do
anything to them.

The second prong on my Fork
of Mojo is the Confident What.
This is all about body language.

We talked about this before,
the Mojito cat, now we've

talked about the other
types of Unconfident Whos.
What do they do?

That would be the Wall Flower,
and then we have the Napoleon,
aka the over-owner.

Go back and look
at those videos,

you'll know about the
Mojito cat, the Wall Flower

Cat, and the Napoleon
cat, and those three

are examples of
the Confident What.

The third prong on
the Fork of Mojo

that you see right
here-- bing, that would
be the Confident Where.

Bush dwellers, tree dwellers,
beach dwellers, right?

Where do they accentuate
their mojo-osity right now.
What about the Confident How.
That's your job.

Your homework is to
find the Confident How.
Play is pray.
Pray is Mojo.

Playing with your cat is not
like taking a little time out.

It's about as important
as walking your dog.

It gets the Confident
Who out in your house.

Play is the most
important thing that you

can do with your cat
on a daily basis.

So many of the problems that
you guys are writing in to me

about, Jackson why
does my cat do this,

don't worry about why they're
doing it half the time.
First, start by playing.

How can you also bring
out Mojo in your cat?

You're going to think I'm
crazy, but this is true.
It's about food, people.
Bio appropriate diet.

When you're talking
about an animal that

is so close to wild
you can taste it,

that's the thing, they're
not out there hunting,
but what do they need?

Their body informs
their Mojo just as much

as their mind
informs their Mojo.

So don't forget, your cats
are obligate carnivores,

and they need to eat meat, and
they need to eat it every day.
I am vegan, I do not eat animal.
My cats have to.

You can cater to
the Confident Who

with every moment of every day,
whether it is scheduling them

through play and diet, whether
it is building up in the world,

or building down in the world,
where their Mojo comes to bear,

I'm telling you folks,
the why about your cat

doing what they do in
your house falls away
when you cater to the Mojo.

How can I help my cat
demonstrate their Cat Mojo?

Tell me about it, write to
me here, right down here

at the bottom, leave a
comment, subscribe to this,

so you can find out
what's going on next.

Also you can find me on my
website jacksongalaxy.com,

you can find me, I am on
the Animalist network,

clearly, because this is
the Animalist network,

also you can find me on
Facebook, and on Twitter,
and on Instagram.

I am wherever you are, and
I'd love to hear from you.

If you haven't noticed, take a
look at this, will you please,
right behind me.

This is my man Benny,
he was presented to me,

we were doing a case for "My
Cat from Hell" in San Diego,

and at the end of the case,
these wonderful people,

their friend, her name
is Kathryn Johncox,

and Catherine presented me with
this gorgeous piece of artwork.
And I wish her all the best.

Catherine, you rock
my world, I've never

seen anything capture
Benny as much as you did,
and I mean that's him.

That's that boy who launched the
book, who launched the career,

and now he looms
over me, telling me
what I'm doing wrong.
Thank you so much, Catherine.

And I thank you for joining
me, for doing your homework,

for loving your cat,
until the next time

we meet folks, all light,
all love, all Mojo to you.
You're a bad cat,
I'm not a bad cat,
You're a bad cat,
I'm just misunderstood.
Meow.

comments.text:
When you play with a laser pointer with your cat, from the cat's 
perspective, are they playing with YOU or are they just playing with the 
laser dot? Is that difference important?﻿
comments.author: Fragacide

comments.text:
I've recently gained the trust of 2 outside cats (Beast) and (Babee)they 
walk around my house everyday, and they are both really playful and 
lovable, but my inside cat is not playful nor cuddly. .. am I doing 
something wrong with my inside cat (Belle)?﻿
comments.author: Lilybeth Rodriguez

comments.text: Great video!﻿
comments.author: Bhawna Mundotia

comments.text: My cat eats cat mix she eats cereal lol :P﻿
comments.author: Ali Mughal

comments.text:
Love your show! Love it! Love it! Question, my 3 yr old female spay cat has 
been attacking my 10 year old neutered male toy fox terrier. I can't figure 
it out. Do you think playing with her more would help? Could she be 
jealous? Thx! ﻿
comments.author: Nora C

comments.text:
My cat is confident with loads of Mojo! We play with him every day and he's 
an outdoor cat so gets lots of exercise and regularly brings home little 
"gifts" (most of which are rescued and released safely, thankfully!) The 
only upsetting thing is he doesn't ever come up and sit with us for a pet 
or just to chill out. He did when he was a kitten - up until he was nearly 
a year old but he's two now and just doesn't interact with us in an 
affectionate way. Don't know where we're going wrong!!﻿
comments.author: Leanne McQuade

comments.text:
I adopted an 18yr old cat (human years) and no matter how much we play and 
the meal feeds, he meows at me day and night. I have no idea what to do 
with him! At first I thought he was just grieving for his human mom who had 
died but its been months now. Any suggestions?﻿
comments.author: Cheri Westoby

comments.text: Haha very avid talkers! glad to know I am not the only one :)

comments.text:
+Cheri Westoby my cat does that to me too, and at first I thought something

then he's probably just talking to you :)

comments.text: How do I get stray cats to like me?﻿

comments.text: why my cat loves to eat carton sometimes? she bites cardboard!! ﻿

comments.text:
I just have one question: So we have two cats, our orange and white one is 
my older brothers, and the black one is mine. We saved both our cats from 
shelters and I've had Raven (black cat) since my 4th birthday. I'm 14 now, 
almost 15 and I'm not sure why, but Raven always follows me around now. It 
doesn't matter where I am in the house she will follow me, just me, nobody 
else. She won't eat her food unless I'm in the same room, she likes to sit 
in my lap whenever I sit down, and she'll try and follow me to my room. I 
don't really understand the behavior??﻿

comments.text: Hi, Benny! :D﻿

comments.text:
My kitten loves chicken. She goes nuts for chicken. It's like catnip to

comments.text: You need to die, slowly.﻿
comments.author: drinfernogh

comments.text:
Yesterday, my dad's cat, Spazz, was doing what she does best: being a 
spazz. My dad had a chair out in the living room that he would sit in to 
watch tv with me and his cousin, and EVERY TIME he would get up to do 
something, BAM There's Spazz sitting on the chair. Now Spazz, for all 
intents and purposes is a Mojito Cat. She is the friendliest most outgoing 
feline imaginable. (half-calico half something else. cute as a button. 
ANYWAYS) my dad would come back and look at Spazz, she would meow and roll 
over and rub her back on the chair; the whole nine yards. Dad reaches down 
to pet her, she jumps down, tail up, and trots off. That, or just before my 
dad would sit down, "Mrrreaow" (You know, when they add that cute little 
purr into their meow) and bam, there's Spazz, tail up, looking at Daddy. 
This went on for about thre hours, about twenty times before Dad just gave 
up and went to bed. Me and his cousin were convinced that Spazz knew 
exactly what she was doing and knew full well she was pissing him off and 
man was it FUNNY (Not to worry my dad thought it was the funniest damn 
thing in the world, too.) If you have any insight as to why she might have 
been doing that it would be appreciated. Love your shows and your channel!
-Emily﻿
comments.author: PieSpie

comments.text:
By the way, she looks almost identical to your cat, Chippy, just smaller, 
and less white.
comments.author: PieSpie

comments.text:
Hi guys! So my cousin's cat is 2 years old and by watching this video it's 
a raw cat. So I sleep overed for a week at them to see what would happen. 
We fed it meat and took it to the vet. They said feed it more meat. So we 
did. Then we played with it an 1-3 hours a day and it played then I noticed 
that it got nicer so I gave it a couple treats and did that! Thanks so much 
for telling us this and making this video my cousin's cat is lovely and 
loves me the most cos I trained it to do that. Bye!﻿

comments.text:
When u first get your cat and bring it home, it'll sniff your hand before 
the cat lets u pet him/her to get used to ur sent, ( and friends and 
family) trust me I have three cats 
I know a lot about cats ,not tryin to be rude, 
When ur cat gets used to ur sent it knows thta u are its owner and your cat 
won't sniff your hand anymore :3
comments.author: Moon Heart

comments.text:
I can't believe there are people who force cats to be vegan - with 
disastrous results, and I am glad you're not one of those people.  What the 
hell are those people thinking?﻿
comments.author: travelsonic

comments.text:
My female cat has, what I call, "bad" habbit to lick om soft plastic, like 
plastic bags for example. Why does she do that? The noise of her licking 
it, is extremley annoying to me.. How does I made her stop? (removing 
the plastic bags helps ofc, but there is a bit of soft plastic stuck 
on under the couch)﻿
comments.author: Julia Shepherd

comments.text:
Just ignore it 
If u don't ignore it she will keep doing it,but if u ignore it she won't 
know why she is doing it so she will stop.*learned that from Jackson btw
comments.author: Debanti Styless

comments.text:
You need to take your cat to the vet. Cats that eat non-food items (though 
I don't think your cat is EATING the plastic) have something called pika. 
She might not be getting enough of a particular nutrient; your vet can have 
some bloodwork done and check for that. And yes, keep as much plastic away 
from her as possible. The last thing you want to have happen is your cat 
suffocating on plastic.
comments.author: TVC15ohoh

comments.text:
My male cat does that, too, as well as tape and reusable shopping bags.  He 
has a very sensitive stomach and I notice he only licks plastic when his 
stomach bothers him.  I switched him to a grain-free, limited ingredient, 
mostly wet food diet and that really seems to help, he doesn't do it as 
nearly as much as he used to.  In fact sometimes I can even leave plastic 
bags out and he doesn't touch them.
comments.author: Lakshmi Mudgal

comments.text:
Why does my male persian try to dominate me. He almost acts like he's 
trying to mate with my arm. Is this odd for an older neutered cat?﻿
comments.author: shawneeNdNwmn

comments.text:
I have one question, my cat is a larger sized cat, and he is fat...he is a 
picky eater and only likes Meow Mix cat food, aside from the occasional 
treat. But he keeps puking it up. Almost every day...how do I fix this so I 
don't have to clean what looks like uneaten clumps of meow mix? PS: He 
doesn't like canned cat food.﻿
comments.author: Mary Dann

comments.text: My cats do that too!! I don't think that they chew most of their food..
comments.author: Millisa Davis

comments.text:
I hope someone can answer this question, Jackson says that good or bad 
attention is considered attention to a cat and to reinforce good  behavior 
you give attention when they are being good (quiet for example). My 
question is how long do you wait before you give good attention when they 
are in a middle of a crying session? I've heard him say as little as 10 
seconds. Is that really all the time they need? (yes I realize they are 
crying because they are bored or something is wrong, or want to play, and 
I'm trying to address that as well)﻿
comments.author: WhatThatify

comments.text:
Hey Jackson, I have been wondering about my cat's behavior. She's a laid 
back and pretty relaxed cat who loves to have attention and come up to 
people. A mojito cat you could say. My brother comes down from college and 
she loves him as much as she loves everyone else that comes into the house, 
but she gets a little eccentric with him. By eccentric i mean she'll be all 
calm and relaxed one minute with him patting her, but then she starts 
meowing really loudly and chases after him, wanting him to pat her some 
more. She's never done this with anyone else. Sometimes it frightens my 
brother how much she wants his attention to go as far as chase him around 
frantically and demand for attention. Now my brother does play games with 
her such as hide and seek where he basically runs away and hides somewhere, 
drawing her attention to where he could be. So i am wondering if her 
frantic behavior is something related to the games they play.﻿
comments.author: BoleroBakurine

comments.text:
My older cat, every time I come home from work would greet me at the door, 
and then demand food, water, and some play time. She has a daughter I've 
kept from her litter, they are both very loving and cuddly. Though they 
love their cat tree for alone time.
The only problem I am having is they are chewing through my cords, and it's 
super unsafe, any suggestions?﻿
comments.author: Michelle Leong

comments.text:
wrap some sticky tape around your cords for a bit. they usually hate 
touching them
comments.author: Mohsin Abbaas

comments.text:
Maybe apply something that tastes awful onto the cords, so when the cat 
chews it, it will taste disgusting things, and will leave the cords alone :)
comments.author: Mariana Cui

comments.text:
Apple Bitter and you have to play with your cats! They do that sort of 
thing gwhen they are bored because they seek stimulation. :)
comments.author: Ainsleigh Walker

comments.text:
if i say "no" my cat stops doing what she's doing, she just understand it's 
wrong without any punishment :)﻿
comments.author: Clally56

comments.text:
Hi! I have Maxwell, my black & white Norwegian Forest cat 4yrs old & kiki . 
The kitten4 mos. Old tortie. They are both so sweet &are my joy.﻿
comments.author: Darlene lamere

comments.text: The "prongs" of a fork are called tines﻿
comments.author: Kasey Meyer

comments.text: I had no idea what was he talking about! ﻿
comments.author: jurassicperk86

comments.text: Rescued*﻿
comments.author: Paola Garavito

comments.text:
Hey Jackson, I reused a kitten off the streets last December, how can I 
cater to his mojo?
He's bipolar, on somedays he's social and loving and others terrified of my 
family or myself. I play with him and I tried feeding him bio appropriate 
food but he won't eat anything aside from friskier...he just won't eat even 
if he's hungry...What can I do?!﻿
comments.author: Paola Garavito

comments.text:
Just feed him what he likes.. Cats will starve themselves if they don't 
like what you give them.. So if he likes Friskies then let him eat that 
food.. Now most dogs will eat what you put in front of them.. I have only 
seen small dogs act finicky like cats...
comments.author: Millisa Davis

comments.text:
Thank you for another great episode of cat mojo. You have been thinking in 
a totally different yet good way on how to best care for my 6 month old 
kitten Banjo. I love to take time out to play with him everyday and it is 
making a huge difference to our relationship and I have to say it's for the 
better.﻿
comments.author: Vicki Mainard

comments.text:
Hi Jackson, why does my cat keep putting his butt on my face when I sleep? 
It does make me feel loved, but his butt?﻿
comments.author: Birdie Blue

comments.text: +Ainsleigh Walker It's a really smelly compliment hahaha
comments.author: CA Tol

comments.text:
Cats have scent glands there basically he's saying 'Hello' and 'I trust 
you'. Take it as a compliment!
comments.author: Ainsleigh Walker

comments.text: I think cats do that for warmth.
comments.author: Supercrafter

comments.text:
So I been playing with my cat everyday since I adopted her. I am sure I 
switch up her toys every other day or so... and it seems like shes getting 
bored of them.. so now since shes bored she tends to nip and claw at feet. 
What are some toys that you recommend?﻿
comments.author: Ashley Strongheart

comments.text:
Thank u so much for all your help. This videos have help me understand my 
little Habibi. ﻿
comments.author: Carmy♥

comments.text:
I have this friend who likes to say how well behaved and cute my darlings 
are compared to her 'feral' cat. 
Quick summary, she got misty. She and her family did no training and let 
him do whatever for a few months, then later continually scream and beat 
him at the slightest thing. Apparently, he was 'psycho' but I could cuddle 
him just fine when I came over. He ended up running away. 
Then they buy a kitten. I know. Thy let him scratch their legs and 
furniture, even encouraging t because 'he needs toget it out of his system 
while he's little.' Shocker, he does it more now that he's older and 
stronger. Same deal, screaming and beating. I come over, pick him up and 
cuddle him - he even purrs. So cute! <3
They're thinking about giving this one away and buyig a new one because 
it's 'feral'. How do I say 'It's not the cat, it's you' nicely?
And don't worry about the beatigs. I axeggerated (... I forget how to spell 
that sorry) it with the word beatings a bit, but only because thy don't 
want to pay vet bills. 
And to be honest, ther horses and dog are biting now too. Please help me 
help their animals!﻿

My cat has never been from hell. If something goes wrong, it's because I

eat it. When my cat is happy, the house is silent. When I am woke up at 
5am, it means to open the door so she can watch the birds. (House Cat). 
Yes, she has me trained very well.﻿

Jackson
I enjoy everything you do; I have always lived with cats, Tiger, Hairy,

Don﻿

I have 2 questions....the first one is my male cat is 10 years old and is 
fixed (not sure when before he was 2 ...has no front claws (cat was left in 
the house I moved into) why does he kneed my comforter all the time and 
then bite me and meow.

2nd questions along with that cat I have 2 males 6 year old cats (both 
fixed) and a 2 year old female cat (fixed). We moved into a new house 6 
months. We used to have a problem with the cats peeing/spraying on the 
walls in the old house. They really destroyed the carpets and such. The 
only ones not fixed there were the 2 males that were 6 so before we moved 
into the new place we had them fixed.  The problems is they keep going (not 
everyday) peeing/spraying in the same 2 spots in the house. I have Comfort 
Zone w/Feliway Diffuser in the wall and I have a toy called
Da Bird and a laser I use to play with them. The Diffuser seems to work to 
a degree.
But I would say at least once a week there is some pee on the wall. I wipe

do their business.I do know it isn't the female cat.

Help﻿

comments.author: banapple89

comments.text:
What am I doing wrong?
I love my cat, he is quite peaceful for the most part but somehow I feel 
like something isn't clicking.
1st. He has his cup of food for the whole day in his room and some days he 
doesn't touch his plate, some days he eats it all. I've tried changing the 
type of food but he started throwing up all over the house so we came back 
to the old type and the throwing up stopped. He isn't fat nor too skinny 
either.
2nd. He sleeps ALL THE TIME! I've tried to get him up and be active, I 
tried playing with him but he is so uninterested most of the time that even 
I get bored, throughout the day he runs all over the house as if something 
is chasing him! And then I get up to try to chase him and he runs as if 
playing tag! It's hilarious but it's the most exercise he gets.
3rd. He doesn't like being held! Or petted. I have family come over and he 
meows at them when they get close to him and then if they try to pick him 
up he meows as if he were complaining. He doesn't do that with me because I 
guess he is used to me but he does seem to want me to let him go. And no I 
don't pick him up or carry him around too much.
4th. When we sleep some nights rarely he does the crazy running and also 
the talking, goes around the house meowing as if he is either calling me or 
someone or just talking to himself. He also comes to the bed and finally 
sleeps right between my legs, which is about the only closeness I get to 
have with him so I do the best I can to stay still and let him sleep.
Finally, is all of this behavior normal??? He is antisocial but he doesn't 
hide, or stay mainly on the ground, he is usually up on something, couch, 
tree, bed, looking out the window or on the tallest box close to the 
ceiling.﻿
comments.author: banapple89

comments.text:
Dear Jackson,
I have 2 Russian Blues, one over 2 y.o. and one less than a year old. The 
oldest one was at home first.
The introduction has been done according to the rules and they live, eat, 
leak each other and play just fine. However Dexter (the oldest one) doesn't 
tolerate Jojo (the youngest) near me by growling and spiting. Never a 
fight. Worse case scenario Dexter just leaves.
I would like to have both at ease close to me and cancel any 
jalousie/territory instinct or help in some ways. When I pet Jojo, Dexter 
is watching me with a bad look. I don't know if I help Jojo feeling part of 
the gang or if I badly tease Dexter's territory/jealousy instinct…
I would appreciate some pointers to live easily with love and harmony :)
Thank you!
Cat﻿
comments.author: catherine vaganay

comments.text:
My cat mostly invit me to play with him ..he jump on the side curve his 
back ..move his head strangly and i run after him he ran away ...and then i 
go hide in a room and pick up his toys to make him hunt ..﻿
comments.author: weralasbiru

comments.text:
I just got a new cat in november, and she has given me loads of problems.

We already have a male cat (6 years old). He's calm, and cuddly.
And she (6 months old now) Is all over the house, playfull and cuddly.

But.. She pees in the house. Not in the litter box.
I tried everything.

I bought an extra litter box, I tried training her...

She still pees on the couch, the corners of the house and in the beds.

I don't know what to do. But this seems to happen everytime she has, to say 
it as it is, taken a dump.

She burries her poo in the litter, then, she goes to the closest corner 
(away from any of the litter boxes) and pees.
I am frustrated. I empty the litterbox 5 times a day, and everytime I hear 
her go into the box to poo, I run up to empty it imidiatly. but it's still 
like she refuses to pee in the box right after she pooed in it. Please. 
Help. I dont know what I am doing wrong﻿
comments.author: Caroline “VampireCherry” Andersen

comments.text:
You are going about it all wrong your cat is nervous! Cats do that they are 
unsure of their place in the house. Also emptying the box that much just 
adds to the problem check out this guy's video on litter.
comments.author: Ainsleigh Walker

comments.text:
Try to put a litterbox on or near the place she pees for maybe it's a 
territorial issue.
comments.author: DiekeDrake

comments.text:
I think there are several possibilities. 1 she is becoming adult and this 
will stop when she will be sterilized (i know this is the case with male 
cats, not sure about the females), some cats just dont like to pee in the 
dirty litter box, some cats are very picky about how clean their bathrooms 
are. I got rid of my problem (i have like 4+cats and one male cat had the 
same problem) when i bought 2 extra huge plastic boxes (i think its 
75cm*50cm). it is said that for a cat you would need +1 litter box. aka if 
u have 2 cats, then 3 litter boxes. but in my case the 2 huge ones worked 
very well. also it can be the litter material itself. the extra clumping 
works best for my case.

Also if it wont fix your problem, then i think you should get your cat 
checked @ the doc, cuz she might have some bladder issues. but i dont think 
this is the case right now. Well good luck and dont punish your cat, 
because she doesnt misbehave on purpose :)
comments.author: batmannu

comments.text:

at my grandma's always like laying on them, I don't mind them sleeping on 
them, but they like clawing them. They kind of kneed them but with their 
claws. How do I get them to not kneed them but just let them sleep on them 
with out tearing them up?﻿
